comments.commentBody:
He'll last a good long time, most likely the entire term, as he has his cronies everywhere; those he has chosen for high office in government will protect him fanatically, as he is their additional meal ticket. Everywhere there is money that has to be protected he'll have someone who is willing to accept pay instead of litigation.
Well, his supporters wanted him, now they have him and can see what kind of a person they have chosen. With his ideas of isolation and protectionism, he'll quickly undo the improvement the economy showed prior to his election.
His idea that using his presidency to establish business deals abroad and that he can do it as he protected by the law reflects an acceptance of corruption that rivals that of any Third-World potentate. Good luck, U.S.A.

The old "saw", a picture is worth a thousand words would have done Hillary Clinton a world of good at one of the debates...it was well known that Trump was involved in at least 3,500 lawsuits over the past few decades. He constantly sued the type of voter he was courting with his lies and distortions. She should have had a facesheet from each of these lawsuits (readily available at a clerk's office) stacked in front of her at one of the debates. The several foot high visual reminder of Trump's propensity to sue would have been stark evidence of his true nature and those who may have wavered on him would have been able to see for themselves what he truly does in his everyday business activities. Another lost opportunity...

The worst thing about Trump is not that he is ignorant of issues, blind to his defects, uncertain in his beliefs and shameless in his personal behavior. It is that he lives in a fantasy world where he is never wrong and that everything he does is of monumental proportions.   This distortion of reality can be seen in all his utterances, from exaggerations to outright fabrications, and all redound to his credit. Take the 6 year birther lie.  When he finally puts an end to that malevolent campaign, he takes credit for putting the issue to rest.  When he is about to be found guilty of fraud, he announces that he is making a personal sacrifice in paying for his misdeeds.  How could such a man convince so many people that he is deserving of trust is truly mind boggling. Good as our revered Lincoln was, he missed the boat on the immense capacity of people to be fooled.
We knew this..  If voters didn't have enough sense to not elect him, then the Republican party should have had enough decency to not let him run as a Republican.

Now retired, I practiced law for thirty-seven years. I spent many of those years as a litigator. What this article fails to point out is that, as fewer plaintiffs' attorneys take cases on a contingency basis, and as litigation costs continue to skyrocket, most plaintiffs with extremely solid cases just can't afford to see their claims through to trial, and often will forego their claims for this reason. Defendants like the President-elect and his ilk know this, and for those plaintiffs who soldier on, these defendants will essentially bankrupt plaintiffs with excellent claims against them, through abusive pre-trial tactics, as they know these plaintiffs often cannot afford the six or seven figure legal fees. What this article tells me then, is that this is just the tip of the iceberg of legitimate legal claims against the man.

Again and again, Trump's misdeeds demonstrate how our laws have been written by the wealthy, for the wealthy. This is not about Trump any more; it's about the corruption of lawmakers in every state and on every level of government, from local to federal.

"It's not illegal," has become the phrase adopted by spokespeople for wealthy individuals whose actions are highly questionable and unethical, if not technically illegal.

But why aren't these self-enrichment schemes illegal? Why are no laws being passed to stop corruption? We read about high-level corruption every day, and yet nothing, not one thing, is done about it in Congress, the Senate, or in any state legislatures.

The answer is: because so many members of legislative bodies are complicit! It costs a literal fortune to run for any office these days, and no one is elected without falling into the debt of corporate puppeteers with bottomless pockets.

Unless the middle and working classes agree to come together over this issue, we will all be robbed blind, over and over, by people writing laws to favor one class, and one class only, over everyone else. The more this corruption becomes entrenched in law, the harder it will be to root it out and get rid of it.

This is a sad time in the history of our fragile American republic. Like Russia and China, our country is now headed down the path towards an authoritarian-style, oligarchic, crony-capitalist state, ruled by a personality cult of charismatic strongmen.

With his control of all three branches of government, as well as the collapse of the political parties and the lack of an independent voice in the corporate-owned news media, it is difficult to see how he can be stopped.

It is ironic that our republic survived the Civil War, two World Wars and the nuclear-age Cold War, but may yet end in an Orwellian whimper, as our democracy is quietly transformed into a corporate, oligarchical state, where only the strong survive.

We owe it to the preceding generations who fought so hard to protect our republic to do all we can to prevent such a sad outcome from taking place.
Each and every lawsuit needs media investigation.

Donald Trump and other individuals and corporations with deep pockets know how litigation can work in their favor, win or lose. Settling is just part of the cost of doing business as usual. Settlements generally mean the defendant is not obliged to admit wrongdoing, a generous Get Out Of Jail Free card for people whose actions have harmed others. While Mr. Trump is in office, his business fortunes will almost certainly rise like a tide that lifts a fleet of yachts. Those with cases against him will be willing to settle, as the Trump University litigants so quickly did. And President Trump can sleep well knowing he can bear the burden, pay almost any price to stay afloat and end his term in office more well-heeled than before.
Doug Giebel
Big Sandy, Montana

I would have preferred that the Trump University lawsuits be settled in court. Although I understand the plaintiffs' need to recover their losses timely and their agreement to settle the Trump University lawsuits, I am also dismayed by the provisions of the settlement terms--no admission of liability on Trump's part. Apparently Trump, who has failed so frequently in past business ventures, is now, as President elect of the US, just too big to fail.
It certainly is true that a President preoccupied with many lawsuits against him would not be able to effectively do his job as President. So why doesn't some judge dismiss all the lawsuits pending against him, leaving him free to run his businesses and the USA?
President Nixon was also considered too big to fail. People of my age remember what a crook Nixon was. We were told to understand, for vague unspecified reasons, that Ford's pardoning of Nixon was in the best interests of the Country--Nixon was just too big to fail. Too many took away from Watergate that lesson that you could get away with lots of bad stuff if you were powerful enough.
If we continue to agree to allow special rules for our Presidents, we are looking at a bleak future.

The media did not take him seriously enough, on too many occasions his lies were left unchallenged.  His history of betraying people who trusted him was well established  and could have received more publicity during the campaign.  The lawsuits, his abuse of neighbors in Scotland and his racist past, should have gotten even more play.  Instead, publishers pretended to be balanced by letting his lies gain as much weight as Hillary's truths.  Confusion and caution, may have killed the country.

But we knew all of this, each and every bit, and we elected him anyway.

www.endthemadnessnow.org
